stimulusHtml:
The distribution of four populations of giant kangaroo rats, Dipodomys ingens, living on the same island when it was first surveyed in 1789 are shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Four populations of D. ingens in 1789

In 1852, there was a large earthquake which altered the islandâ€™s geography, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. Map of the island following the 1852 earthquake

The island was surveyed again in 2015, and scientists determined that the giant kangaroo rats originally in population A are now to be considered as a new species.

Which of the following best explains the mechanism that caused this speciation event in the giant kangaroo rats of population A?
choicesHtml: The animals in population A were exposed to different predators and had to modify their fur color to be better camouflaged.
The animals in population A were reproductively isolated from those in populations B, C, and D.
The animals in population A accumulated fewer genetic mutations, adapting to their microclimate.
The animals in population A mate at different times of year, causing their gametes to be incompatible with those from animals in populations B, C, and D.
